awd_titl_txt: Three Compliance Instruments for Axial Volcano to Observe Long Term Evolution of the Magma Chamber and in Support of OOI Observations
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite decades of observations, how magma migrates and is stored within volcanoes remains poorly understood because there are few means to continuously monitor changes within magma chambers beneath volcanoes. Such measurements are needed to understand when and how the gradual emplacement of magma finally triggers an eruption.  The instrumentation developed will provide the potential to monitor changes in the magma content continuously beneath undersea volcanoes and thereby provide a better understanding of volcano processes that can also be applied to volcanos on land that pose a major hazard to millions of people.

Axial Volcano, a large, very active undersea volcano offshore the US West Coast is currently monitored using sensors that transmit data through the NSF supported Ocean Observatories Initiative cable to shore.  Sensors on these cables measured changes in the compliance of seafloor preceding and following an eruption in 2015 associated with changes in the magma chamber, but the noise level of these sensors limited the sensitivity of the observations and the observation period to the winter months when the compliance signal was larger. New compliance sensors with better sensitivity and a lower noise level will be constructed using more optimal sensors and placed on the seafloor beneath large shields that protect the sensors from noise from ocean currents. Compliance, a measure the deformation of the seafloor under the loading of long period ocean waves, depends on the elastic properties of the underlying Earth and thereby to the fraction of magma within the magma chamber. The current shielding developed will also have applicability for reducing the noise levels for the horizontal components of broadband seismometers installed on the seafloor. Ocean bottom seismometers are critical to understanding many Earth processes, but the high noise levels due to ocean floor currents limits the types and quality of observations that can be made.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Despite decades of observations, how magma migrates and is stored within volcanoes remains poorly understood because there are few means to continuously monitor physical changes within magma chambers. Recently, measurements of seafloor compliance derived from two Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) array instruments were used to demonstrate an evolution in the average shear velocity within the Axial Volcano magma chamber from before to after a 2015 eruption of the volcano, providing unique but spatially limited evidence for an evolving magma chamber. Axial Volcano is a large volcano lying on the axis of the Juan de Fuca ridge offshore of Oregon. Compliance measurements use measurements of the deformation of the seafloor under the loading of very low frequency ocean waves to determine the elastic properties of the sub-seafloor.

The research was focused on the engineering and construction of three new compliance instruments- current shielded, broadband ocean bottom seismometers (OBS) designed for multiyear deployments in deep water carrying both a differential pressure gauge (DPG) and a high sampling rate (100Hz) absolute pressure gauge (APG). The three important engineering components of the research are 1) designing for multi-year deployments 2) building and testing the effectiveness of large covering shields to reduce the noise levels for deep seafloor seismic sensors through shielding the sensors from current and 3) combining APG and DPG observations to optimize the signal to noise for compliance observations while ensuring accurate calibration. Shielded instruments that can be deployed for multiple year deployments measuring seismic, geodetic and oceanographic signals will be required for future subduction zone observations targeted at seismic and tsunami hazards. The currently available OBSs have limited duration, poorly calibrated pressure sensors and provide noisy data on the horizontal components because of noise from tilting under ocean currents.

We constructed three compliance instruments and made a series of short deployments of these instruments on the seafloor of Axial Volcano in May 2022. We obtained the highest signal to noise and widest bandwidth compliance data ever obtained on the seafloor, exceeding the goals outlined in the proposal. The instruments are ready to be deployed during longer duration experiments in the future which could provide measurements of variations in magma content of the Axial Volcano magma chamber preceeding eruptions.

Differential pressure gauges (DPG) are extensively deployed within existing fleets of ocean bottom seismometers, but it has always been difficult to accurately calibrate the response of the sensor at long period effecting their utility for seismic observations.  By making simultaneous observations using both DPG and APG sensors we have been able to accurately calibrate the DPG at low frequency and at seafloor pressures and temperatures.
